title-group.article-title: Do Tax Revolt Provisions Influence Tuition and Fee Levels? Evidence from the States using Recent Panel Data

permissions.copyright-statement: Â© 2015 Board of Directors of the Journal of Education Finance, Inc.

abstract.p: Previous research has shown that Tax Revolt Provisions (TRPs) aimed at limiting state government revenues and/or expenditures, negatively impact public higher education funding. This analysis explores the influence of these same types of policies on average in-state undergraduate tuition and fees at public four-year colleges and universities. Employing a data set spanning 13 years and using an econometric estimator appropriate for finite samples with time-invariant variables related to unit-effects, the findings indicate that TRPs matter, but not equally. Tax and Expenditure Limitations, regardless of provision type, share no discernible relationship with tuition and fees. Conversely, Supermajority requirements are associated with higher levels of tuition and fees by approximately 5.5% to 6.6%. The findings suggest that as policy-makers and researchers seek out the drivers of rising tuition and fees, it would be prudent to take into consideration both the role played by traditionally considered variables and that played by state fiscal policy as well.

p.mixed-citation: This paper was previously presented at the 2013 National Education Finance Conference, the 2013 annual meeting of the Association for the Study of Higher Education, and the Education Innovation Institute.

For the purposes of this analysis tuition and fees are measured as the average listed in-state price at state-supported four-year institutions of higher education that covers the student portion of the ex- penses of providing a public university undergraduate education as well as mandatory fees, not includ- ing room and board and other elective fees.
"Price-sensitive students" are those students who tend to be more sensitive to changes in listed tuition and fee levels because they are from low income families (Gwartney et al. 2009).
Please note that the Carnegie Foundations definition only includes baccalaureate degree granting institutions for which at least 10% of the degrees offered are designated as bachelors degrees.

Although these authors find interdependence by modeling the relationship simultaneously, I sug- gest that instead of being a case of simultaneity this may be better understood as sequential games with incomplete information and thus their results may suggest sub-optimal Nash Equilibria (see Achen (2000) for examples of this as applied to national budgets).

This is not to suggest that institutions can increase tuition and fees indefinitely. Instead, the goal is to highlight the role played by tuition and fees in university revenue structure and how institutions, even when limited by state policy or policy makers, can often times still raise tuition and fees to make up budgetary gaps that arise.
To be clear, the TELs under investigation here are those that have been adopted at the state, not municipal, level.

After a basic examination of the data, it does appear that in states with SMRs the citizen ideology score is slightly but statistically significantly more conservative (r= -.1454, p=.0001) but this finding is merely descriptive not causal.

The FEVD estimator has recently come under scrutiny from some scholars (see Political Analy- sis 19(2), 2011). However, after careful consideration of the original article, the articles critical of the method, and the rebuttal articles, I am confident that the method is both valid and appropriate based on the goals of the current study. Additionally, while some might not consider this a reasonable solution for the problem of time-invariant regressors, recent studies suggest that though flawed in some instances, the estimators usefulness is still evident if the finite sample properties of the estimator can be met, if important theoretical variables are time-invariant, and the inclusion of fixed-effects is vital (Zhu, 2013) all of which is the case for the current study.

The null hypothesis for this test is that the FE and RE models are both consistent and efficient. The rejection of the null means that there are systematic differences between the models and that the FE model is more reasonable and hence, preferred (see Cameron and Trivedi, 2005,2010 for more details).
In the formal explanation of the FEVD model, the unexplained part of u is denoted as h.

The author did consider employing a Lagged Dependent Variable (LDV). However, the reason for not employing a LDV is that the inclusion of such a control in the model did not improve its fit dramati- cally (.950 to .970) so as to support such an inclusion as another control for possible endogeneity or autocorrelation, especially when the data are heavily trended (Achen, 2000). In other words, it is likely that in this instance the cure would be worse than the disease.
